PHILADELPHIA, January 8, 1903.
To
His Excellency Theodore Roosevelt,
President of the United States
Sir:
div1.p:
At a stated meeting of the College of Physicians of
Philadelphia, held on the 7th inst., the following preambles and
resolutions were adopted:

“WHEREAS, the late Major Walter Reed, Surgeon U. S. Army, has
left his family in very straitened circumstances and

“WHEREAS, Major Reed's scientific researches by which he dis-
covered the means through which Yellow Fever was spread by the
Mosquito, have practically abolished Yellow Fever in Cuba so that
it is now free from this scourge for the first time in 170 years,
have revolutionized our methods of Quarantine against the disease,
and are worth many millions of dollars to our Commerce, in addition
to the saving of thousand of lives, therefore

“RESOLVED, by the College of Physicians of Philadelphia that
the bill about to be introduced into Congress giving Mrs. Reed a
pension of $4000- a year is heartily urged upon our Senators and
Representatives in Congress as a most desirable and commendable
recognition of Major Reed's splendid work for his country and for
science.

“RESOLVED, that a copy of these preambles and resolutions be
sent e President of the United States and the Committees on
Pensions of the Senate and House of Representatives.”
div1.closer:
Respectfully, Arthur V. Medgo Vice President
attest,
Thomas R. Neilson,
Secretary.
